dc:description: MT-TI is a mitochondrial gene that encodes for mitochondrially-encoded tRNA for isoleucine, it is located on the heavy stand of mitochondrial DNA spanning 69 nucleotides 4263-4331. MT-TI was first reported in association with hypertrophic cardiomyopathy in 1996 (Merante et al. 1996, PMID: 8889580). Three variants have been seen in five probands in three publications (PMIDs: 8889580, 12767666, 37124643). One homoplastic variant m.4300A>G is seen in most cases, including in a family segregating to 16 affected family members. Each variant has supporting histochemical and biochemical functional evidence from patient biopsies. This gene-disease relationship is also supported by expression studies (PMID: 8889580, 34265302). In summary, there is MODERATE evidence supporting the relationship between MT-TI and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy. The ClinGen Hereditary Cardiovascular Disease GCEP approved this classification on the meeting date December 18, 2023.

evidence.dc:description:
supported by 2 other papers with patient heart tissue 
Merante et al., 1996 PMID: 8889580 PCR amplification from heart tissue of all tRNA genes and directly sequenced – variant in siblings and mother 
Giordano et al., 2013 PMID: 21945886 Northern blot analysis of patient and control cardiac muscle RNA

Northern blot analysis of 22 mt-tRNAsteady-statelevels among 5 mouse tissues
found MT-TI expressed in mouse hearts
evidence.rdfs:label: Northern blot analysis of 22 mt-tRNAsteady-statelevels among

evidence.dc:description:
Proband: Based on sk muscle histochemistry --> respiratory chain biochemistry of muscle homogenate --> combined respiratory chain defect involving complexes I, III and IV 
- All of these contain mtDNA-encoded sub- units 
- Activity of complex II (entirely nuc-encoded subunits) normal --> prompting testing on mtDNA 
No abnormalities found in sk muscle of clinically unaffected mother. 
Sequencing of mtDNA: m.4277T.C variant in DHU loop of mt-tRNAIle (MTTI) gene 
- Region not strongly conserved phylogenetically 
- Confirmed variant homoplasmic in sk muscle and peripheral lymphocytes of both proband and clinically unaffected mother
Robust functional evidence & 16 segregations with disease

Steady-state mt-tRNA-Ile levels
- Marked decrease in quantity of the mature mt-tRNA-Ile transcripts from LV of both probands compared with controls (5-10% of controls), but, no obvious size change in the mutant form. 
- Similar decrease (10-15% of controls) also observed in sk muscle (clinically unaffected tissue) from proband of family 1, when compared with steady-state levels of mt-tRNALeu(UUR) in the same samples. 
- Cultured skin fibroblasts and myoblasts from both families expressed the molecular defect to a lesser extent (40% and 50% of control values) 
Histochemical analysis - Large numbers of cells devoid of COX activity. Esp evident when dual-stained for both COX and SDH activity. 
- More COX-negative cells in the LV than RV 
- Normal SDH and COX activity in sk muscle from family 1 proband, and no other histochemical features suggestive of mitochondrial disease 
Biochemical analysis 
- Family 1 IV-03: respiratory chain activity in compared between LV and sk muscle as well as between pt and controls --> severe deficiency in complexes I and IV, normal levels of all complexes in sk muscle. 
- Normal levels of all complexes in cultured skin fibroblasts (both families) plus fibroblasts and MyoD-converted myoblasts from family 2.

member.phenotypeFreeText: Proband died at 7mo following sudden onset cyanosis. PM found HCM and mitochondrial hypertrophy in heart tissue

3 affected siblings (ages 21, 36, &39)
Sibling 1 (39): Initial diagnosis incidental at 24yo through echo in setting of traumatic injury screening after MVA – 23mm MWT & EF 27%. Over 15yrs developed progressive HF & got ICD, is currently waiting heart tx
Sibling 2 (36): at 21yo concentric LVH (15mm), EF 42%, frequent PVCs & subsequent ICD
Sibling 3 (21): echo concentric LVH (17mm), EF 40%
All had extensive LGE in almost all segments of LV
Mother has mild LVH phenotype

3 affected siblings (ages 21, 36, &39)
Sibling 1 (39): Initial diagnosis incidental at 24yo through echo in setting of traumatic injury screening after MVA – 23mm MWT & EF 27%. Over 15yrs developed progressive HF & got ICD, is currently waiting heart tx

member.phenotypeFreeText: dx 20yo with non-obstructive HCM. Later experienced CHF, leading to cardiac tx at 34yo
died 14mo after presenting with acute cardiac failure. Nil previous ssx and normal dev. Echo showed LVH, dilatation, and decreased systolic function, structural features confirmed on PM

evidence.dc:description: Lowered respiratory chain activities in endomyocardial biopsy of affected sibling due to heteroplasmic m.4295A>G

Steady-state mt-tRNA-Ile levels
- Marked decrease in quantity of the mature mt-tRNA-Ile transcripts from LV of both probands compared with controls (5-10% of controls), but, no obvious size change in the mutant form. 
- Similar decrease (10-15% of controls) also observed in sk muscle (clinically unaffected tissue) from proband of family 1, when compared with steady-state levels of mt-tRNALeu(UUR) in the same samples. 
- Cultured skin fibroblasts and myoblasts from both families expressed the molecular defect to a lesser extent (40% and 50% of control values) 
Histochemical analysis - Large numbers of cells devoid of COX activity. Esp evident when dual-stained for both COX and SDH activity. 
- More COX-negative cells in the LV than RV 
- Normal SDH and COX activity in sk muscle from family 1 proband, and no other histochemical features suggestive of mitochondrial disease 
Biochemical analysis 
- Family 1 IV-03: respiratory chain activity in compared between LV and sk muscle as well as between pt and controls --> severe deficiency in complexes I and IV, normal levels of all complexes in sk muscle. 
- Normal levels of all complexes in cultured skin fibroblasts (both families) plus fibroblasts and MyoD-converted myoblasts from family 2.
Additional Biochemical analysis PMID:21945886, Confirmed a combined respiratory defect involving complexes I, III, and IV, all of which contain mtDNA-encoded subunits

PMID:21945886 Biochemical analysis of individual mitochondrial respiratory chain complexes on frozen cardiac muscle homogenates (explanted hearts, m.4300A>G)
Confirmed a combined respiratory defect involving complexes I, III, and IV, all of which contain mtDNA-encoded subunits.
